( Figure 4) It is suspended in the cell sap in the form of an emulsion, and this emulsion rapidly degrades upon contact with air [ 16]. Resin is accumulated in the resin canals in parenchyma tissue and in pith [ 38]. ( Figure 5 [ 39]) For Hammond, it is principally in the bark of stems and roots, and only a little part can be found in the leaves [ 15]. Upon wounding, it exudes as pale-yellow tears [ 13]. The number of resin canals and epithelial cells increases yearly and thus the amount of PI and resin in the plant [ 38, 40]. Some studies about the morphological changes of the guayule shrub over time, as well as PI and resin accumulation, try to define the best harvesting time [ 41].
